Award.AwardTitle: Integrated THz Spectroscopy exploiting On-chip Scattering and Device Nonlinearity

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Terahertz (THz) spectroscopy has a wide range of potential applications in imaging, non-destructive quality control, biomedical, chemical and air pollution sensing, cell biology, crystal engineering, identification of explosives and counterfeit drugs. However, lack of adequate and cost-effective instrumentation development in this spectral region has contributed to it being called the 'THz' gap, and has adversely affected the development of its application space. However, with new developments in nanotechnology, material science and optics, there has been a resurgence of active research interest in this frequency range and the research community are approaching the technology development from a broad range of scientific disciplines. The success of this project can enable robust, low-cost integrated, THz spectroscopic systems for the aforementioned applications. Such low-cost solutions for the THz frequency region will enable researchers and scientists engaged in this field to rapidly innovate on new technologies that can find extensive use in our daily lives. The PI also expects that this research will engage and train both graduate and undergraduate students in multi-disciplinary fields, which are vitally important for solving challenging research problems for the future. The PI will also engage high-school seniors from local schools and broadly disseminate the knowledge through his proposed two courses and through publications, seminars and workshops.

THz-based spectroscopy is purported to have a wide range of applications in biomedical and chemical analysis. Current technology to perform THz spectroscopy in the time domain mostly relies on expensive optics including femtosecond lasers, photoconductive substrates, nonlinear optical elements and mechanical components making the system expensive, bulky and not amenable to integration. On the other hand, solid-state technology performs frequency domain spectroscopy using the classical down-conversion architecture. It requires a large bank of frequency synthesizers and multipliers covering the entire THz range making it unsuitable for integration. This proposal presents an electromagnetics-circuits-nonlinear estimation crosscut approach to enable chip-scale THz spectroscopy at room temperature through extraction of spectral information from electromagnetic scattering. The key idea is that an electromagnetic interface between the on-chip receiver and the incoming THz wave itself creates an opportunity to perform spectral analysis of the incident signal, without requiring the traditional receiver following it. This proposal seeks to establish the analytical framework for spectral estimation by measuring on-chip electromagnetic scattering. It proposes techniques to estimate such scattering by measuring on-chip the magnitude of the induced surface current distribution on the planar antenna structure due to the incidence of the THz wave. In addition, this proposal also seeks to exploit nonlinearity of the detectors to extract time-domain signature or phase information of the spectrum of the incident signal. This can potentially enable battery-powered, chip-scale THz spectroscopes for a wide range of sensing and imaging applications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Terahertz spectrum above 100 GHz is emerging as a key electromagnetic spectrum for the next generation of sensing and communication systems. These frequencies correspond to wavelengths that are in the millimeter-scale dimension. This can allow new technologies for high-resolution sensing for gesture recognition, localization for autonomous systems and robots and other cyber-physical systems, and high bandwidth communication for 5G and beyond. To enable this new paradigm of communication and sensing co-existence, there is an urgent need for developing technology that allows such complex THz systems integrated on chip at low cost and at scale. In a review paper in Nature Electronics (supported by this grant), my co-authors and I make an argument that in addition to these properties, such sensors need to be smart and adaptive. Silicon-based integrated circuit technology, that has revolutionized computing and communication, becomes the platform of choice, but silicon devices have inherent frequency limitations making such THz systems in silicon extremely challenging. In addition, incorporating adaptive properties on these systems make this even more challenging. The goal of this proposal was to investigate methodologies that eliminates the classical partitioned approach to system design (and its limitations), and demonstrate cross cut approaches that allow new forms of sensing architectures and adaptive systems at THz.

In this project, we showed a ranges of approaches that allow new ways to extract information from THz signals to enabling new forms of adaptive THz sensors. As an example, we demonstrated an approach to extract spectrum information of THz fields directly from the antenna with sub-wavelength multi-port sensing architecture, eliminating the need for all the non-integrated components required in a traditional architecture. This led to the first single THz chip spectroscope covering a record range of 40-990 GHz, where we employed a series of signal processing techniques to overcome the limitations of the integrated devices. We followed up with another work that created adaptive THz sensor covering 100-990 GHz that is programmable with respect to the incident frequency, polarization and angle of incidence. The wok presents a broader approach where system level programmability is achieved with a distributed approach where the devices are inherently less tunable. The project  also demonstrated programmable THz metasurfaces for beamforming and high power THz sources in silicon.These papers have been cited in high numbers by leading researchers in the community. The project has been involved multiple graduate and undergraduate students over the years. A  senior undergraduate project supported by this work demonstrated an electronic-photonic hybrid system and was presented at a flagship IEEE conference and subsequently invited for a special journal issue. This is a major accomplishment for an undergraduate project work. All the students have been trained in the multiple areas that span high-frequency wireless technology, signal processing, chip design and testing coupled in a very multi-disciplinary program. Many of them have won awards and prestigious fellowships, and are expected to continue to contribute significantly to the future of the wireless communication and sensing industry, as a new generation of 5G technologies develop. We expect the research results from this project to have a major impact in a broader domain of science and technology, in enabling new sensing, imaging and communication platforms and capabilities.
